Article.ArticleTitle: Evaluation of Novel Routes for NO<sub>x</sub> Formation in Remote Regions.

AbstractText: Photochemical cycling of nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>) produces tropospheric ozone (O<sub>3</sub>), and NO<sub>x</sub> is traditionally considered to be directly emitted. The inability of current global models to accurately calculate NO<sub>x</sub> levels, and concurrently, difficulties in performing direct NO<sub>x</sub> measurements in low-NO<sub>x</sub> regimes (several pptv or several tens of pptv) globally introduce a large uncertainty in the modeling of O<sub>3</sub> formation. Here, we use the near-explicit Master Chemical Mechanism (MCM v3.2) within a 0D box-model framework, to describe the chemistry of NO<sub>x</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> in the remote marine boundary layer at Cape Verde. We explore the impact of a recently discovered NO<sub>x</sub> recycling route, namely photolysis of particulate nitrate, on the modeling of NO<sub>x</sub> abundance and O<sub>3</sub> formation. The model is constrained to observations of long-lived species, meteorological parameters, and photolysis frequencies. Only a model with this novel NO<sub>x</sub> recycling route reproduces levels of gaseous nitrous acid, NO, and NO<sub>2</sub> within the model and measurement uncertainty. O<sub>3</sub> formation from NO oxidation is several times more efficient than previously considered. This study highlights the need for the inclusion of particulate nitrate photolysis in future models for O<sub>3</sub> and for the photolysis rate of particulate nitrate to be quantified under variable atmospheric conditions.
